title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The Act "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to facilitate visa issuance and alien admissibility determinations. The system must have name search capacity, linguistic sensitivity, user support, and private sector consultation. The unified electronic database mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be developed in consultation with private sector firms, utilize commercially available platforms, and be continuously adjusted and improved. It should also be searchable based on linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations, and incorporate advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research and methods. The unified electronic data system mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must develop linguistically sensitive algorithms for at least 4 high-priority languages. It should provide easily accessible information about names in different languages and allow communication with experts. Interim reports must be submitted every 6 months by specified government officials. The Secretary of the Treasury, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, and the Director of Central Intelligence must submit a report to Congress on their progress in implementing the requirements of this section. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within 60 days, while guidelines must be issued within 120 days. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the implementation of the data system. Consultation with various government agencies is required. The data system must adhere to technology standards and provide easy access to information for Foreign Service officers issuing visas. The curr_chunk discusses limitations on access to intelligence information in the data system for Foreign Service officers and Federal agents. The Secretary of State, Attorney General, and Director of Central Intelligence must establish procedures to restrict access under certain circumstances.
